Colony Clash: Insect Warfare is a card game where players fight using their chosen insect race to defeat the other players. Players build food production resources and their insect army over the course of the game to achieve victory!
Colony Clash can be played by 2 to 4 players. Each player controls one of four species; the Ant Colony, the Royal Mantis, the Beetle Settlement or the Fly Monarchy. (Additional decks can be added on, see pledge levels and updates!)
What makes this card game unique amongst other card games in the market? 
This game is about card fighting and economy building, with the overall goal of winning by defeating all enemies or win by reaching 100 food stacks. All insect race have their own unique strengths and weaknesses, with some races geared more towards economy building with weak but cheap units, while others have strong military supremacy but expensive units. 
Upkeeping - As part of the rules of the game, you can upkeep up to 5 cards in your hand unless you can pay the upkeep fee for exceeding cards. Upkeep fee is equivalent to the number of excess cards in your hand. For example, if you have 7 cards in your hand, you have 2 upkeep cards, so you will have to pay 2 food at the end of your turn, or pay 2 Hive life points, or discard the card. It’s not just about producing or summoning units, you need to build a large food income in order to use insect skills, produce units, repair your Hive & get Hive life points back. 
Another fun feature of the game, you get to play as those pesty bugs! 


The Core Colony Decks & Leaders
               See the pledge levels and updates for additional decks available as add-ons for the game and unlocked at stretch goals!
You can read the full rules here! (Updated 10/23/13)
  Game Play Variants: 2 to 4 players

Free for All
Game Objective: Reduce opponents Hive health points to zero or or attain a stack of 100 Food.

2 vs 2 Cooperative
Game Objective: Reduce opponent's Hive life points to zero or collectively gain a total stack of 300 Food.

Player turn order - Cooperative

Player 1 & Player 2 versus Player 3 & Player 4
Turn 1 - Player 1
Turn 2 - Player 3
Turn 3 - Player 2
Turn 4 - Player 4

Action Stage applies to all players’ turn.

Game Setup 

1.Choose Faction: Players choose which insect race they wish to play. 
2.Place Hive Card: Each player puts their Hive card in the field. A Hive has 30 Health Points. (If it drops to zero, that player is eliminated.) 
3.Determine Play Order: Select which player begins, play then continues clockwise. 
4.Draw Hand: All players draw 5 cards from their chosen deck and receive 10 Food each. 
5.First Turn: The Action Stage begins now. (See Rule Book Page 4)

Missed out this first time and want to help the next time? Sign up for the mailing list to be notified when the project relaunches! Also, like us on Facebook! We post cool stuff there!
"I. LOVE. THIS. GAME. This game might go into one of my top ten games of the year." - Forrest Bower, Bower's Game Corner Review
"Much of what "Lie Your Face Off!" does is thoroughly enjoyable. It's a card game which hides clever planning, attack-your-buddy antics and real depth behind goofy drawings of children. And sometimes cows." - A Board Game A Day Review
"Lie Your Face Off is highly accessible and pleasingly quick. If you’re a fan of lighter, commercial card games with a traditional feel – or looking for something in that vein – this design should be a good choice." - Jason, iSlayTheDragon Review
"All in all, “Lie Your Face Off!” is a quick and clever little card game that is well worth a look." - Dad's Gaming Addiction Preview
In Lie Your Face Off!, players are siblings who parents have thrown crazy accusations at them. Each player responds to those accusations by weaving complex, barely believable stories of lies and embellishments. Stories with enough lies in them can eventually convince your parents that you are innocent...but only if your siblings don't poke holes in those stories first! But act fast, because your parents are only going to listen to your lies for so long!
This is my first card game. It takes between 15 and 45 minutes to play. Most players pick it up in as little as 5 minutes, and understand the game's strategy after just a one or two playthroughs. It's been in heavy development for over 7 months, and playtested with kids as young as 9, adults as old as...well, I didn't ask..., experienced gamers, and casual players, and they all have one thing to say: they love it!
At every level (except the CLEVER KISS-UP and CREATIVE CONNIVER levels), you'll get, in some form, the base Lie Your Face Off! game. This includes 108 colorful and hilarious lie and embellishment cards to weave into ridiculous stories, to score for big points, and to annoy your opponents with:
I've done all the artwork on the cards, and I really love how they all came out:
The mini-expansion, Your Go-To Lies, adds another deck of cards to the game with a new mechanic: if you don't have a Go-To Lie in your hand and you have to draw a card, you draw a Go-To Lie instead. These lies are more powerful than the regular lies, but at a cost: there's only 54 cards in the expansion deck, and if either the base deck (of 108 cards) or the expansion deck runs out, the game will end. campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
What are the risks and challenges that come with completing your project, and how are you qualified to overcome them?

For a project like ours, the risks and challenges fall into three categories:
1) Overall Non-completion
2) Delays in meeting our estimated delivery dates
3) We do not produce a specific model or change one.

Concerning the risk of Overall Non-completion: we've already completed one massive Kickstarter and are fully aware of the pitfalls. Two things that could cause the non-completion of a Kickstarter are either the loss of our inbound shipments (due to an act of God, pirates or war), or a massive disaster (fire, flood) that levels our facility. Either of those events might be disastrous, however we carry full insurance on our facility and insure every shipment, no matter the size, against loss and damage.

Obviously either of the above tragic events would create delays in meeting our estimated delivery dates, and that brings us to the second category: delays. We learned a lot during our first Kickstarter. However, delays are simply part of the cycle of business and it is our wisdom, training, and experience that would help us mitigate and work through any delay. Some delays are easy to solve, such as replacing a printer that is creating barcodes that a particular USPS hub is having a problem reading. Other delays are out of our hands, such as the 2012 longshoreman strike that delayed two of our overseas containers. We have even intentionally created delays when we chose to change models already in production to make them better.

Lastly there is the risk we will not produce a specific model shown. This will only occur if there is not enough interest in the model measured by the number of backers that actually pledge for a buy in level model. This event did not occur in our previous Kickstarter but is nonetheless still a risk. In the event this situation develops we will issue a refund or credit depending on your desire for the buy in pledge amount for the model. Also we reserve the right to modify pieces shown to meet production requirements.

In summary we have the knowledge, wisdom and know how to prevent, solve, and work through just about any problem that we will face and will do everything possible to make this an exciting and enjoyable event.
